function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Use of snowball method to identify publications may result in biased selection of literature, leading to incomplete understanding of biophilic design.","Impact":"Incomplete understanding of biophilic design may hinder the ability to develop effective architectural strategies for mitigating contagious diseases.","Mitigation":"Implement a structured search methodology that includes multiple databases and sources of literature to avoid bias in selection.","Technologies":"Literature review software and databases for structured search and review.","People":"Researchers, architects, and designers focusing on biophilic design in the context of contagious disease mitigation.","Owner":"Research institutions, architectural firms, and academic departments."},{"Description":"Selection of limited literature on the development of relevant concepts may lead to a narrow perspective on the emergence of biophilic design.","Impact":"Narrow perspective may result in the overlooking of key insights and principles essential for integrating biophilic design into contagious disease mitigation strategies.","Mitigation":"Conduct a comprehensive review of literature spanning various periods and sources to capture a holistic understanding of the development of relevant concepts.","Technologies":"Literature review software, academic databases, and digital libraries for comprehensive literature search.","People":"Researchers, architects, and designers seeking to understand the historical evolution of biophilic design.","Owner":"Research institutions, architectural firms, and academic departments."},{"Description":"Limited representation of interdisciplinary knowledge may restrict the applicability of biophilic design to address contagious disease propagation in the built environment.","Impact":"Restricted applicability may hinder the development of effective strategies for integrating biophilic design with sustainable architecture to mitigate the spread of contagious diseases.","Mitigation":"Incorporate literature from diverse subfields of architecture and environmental science to ensure a comprehensive understanding of interdisciplinary knowledge relevant to biophilic design.","Technologies":"Literature review software, academic databases, and digital libraries for accessing interdisciplinary literature.","People":"Researchers, architects, environmental scientists, and public health experts interested in leveraging biophilic design for disease mitigation.","Owner":"Research institutions, architectural firms, and academic departments."}]}
